I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
senior unsecured loan totaling up to $10,000,000 to the Kyrgyz Investment and Credit Bank 
(KICB) for small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) finance in the Kyrgyz Republic. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
2.  In most developing countries, SMEs are important supporters of economic growth and 
key contributors to poverty reduction through increases to individual incomes and employment 
creation. In the Kyrgyz Republic, private sector enterprises grew to become an important part of 
the  economy  following  the  collapse  of  the  Soviet  Union.  The  total  SME  contribution  to 
employment increased from 12.8% in 2006 to 14.2% in 2009, and the contribution to gross 
domestic product (GDP) grew from 45.2% to 45.8% over the same period.1  While the overall 
input of SMEs to the country’s economy is significant, it is important to note that there were 
minimal increases in SME employment and contribution to GDP from 2006 to 2009. 
 
3.  Growth  in  the  SME  sector  has  been  hampered  by  a  number  of  factors.  A  2010 
International Finance Corporation (IFC) study on the SME sector in the Kyrgyz Republic cites a 
difficult investment climate, cumbersome procedures, and, in particular, a lack of access to 
finance  as  “hindrances  to  business  development”.2   Access  to  finance  was  also  severely 
curtailed due to political strife in 2010. Bank lending has increased as a result of stabilization of 
the political situation and continued strengthening of the economy, but a gap in SME funding 
needs remains, as banks continue to focus on large, top-tier companies that are perceived to 
have lower risks.3 
 
4.  The  provision  of  medium  and  long-term  financing  to  SMEs  is  essential  for  these 
companies to be able to invest in the technology and capital needed to increase productivity and 
competitiveness. To expand access to finance in the Kyrgyz Republic, the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) began exploring possible opportunities in 2009 with banks with a strong market 
presence, good distribution networks, and experience in commercial and SME lending. KICB 
was selected as a potential borrower based on its desire and ability to expand its SME portfolio, 
its  sound  credit  profile,  strong  shareholders,  and  its  interest  in  establishing  a  longer-term 
relationship with ADB. This will be the first investment in the Kyrgyz Republic supported by 
ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
5.  KICB  is  a  joint  stock  company  incorporated  in  2001.  KICB’s  mission  is  to  provide 
commercially viable banking services to a broad base of the population that contributes to the 
economic growth of the Kyrgyz Republic and, in particular, to SMEs, which were seriously 
affected  by  the  recent  turmoil.  KICB  provides  a  range  of  loan  and  deposit  products  for 
companies and individuals that are appropriate for the small size of the Kyrgyz Republic’s 
economy, and the small size of business and household financing needs. KICB is the third

largest bank in the country in terms of total assets ($144.7 million as of 30 June 2011). It has 18 
branches, 9 subbranches, 46 ATMs, and 400 staff. As of the end of June 2011, KICB had a 
10.5% market share in terms of total banking loans, 10.8% in terms of deposits, and 11.0% in 
terms of total assets.4 The allocation of KICB’s loans is 60% corporate and 40% retail. 
 
6.  KICB’s SME business is part of its broader retail segment and represented 17% of the 
retail portfolio as of the end of August 2011. KICB has been active in the retail segment and with 
SME lending since 2005 with the help of the technical assistance (TA) from the European Bank 
for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD). Female borrowers constitute 45% of this portfolio 
(as of August 2011), which is a focal market for KICB.5 KICB targets SMEs by segmenting them 
by size into micro and small enterprises (loans of $250–$10,000 equivalent) and SMEs (loans of 
$10,000–$100,000  equivalent).  KICB  does  not  provide  microfinance  loans.  SME  loans  are 
secured  and  cover  a  wide  range  of  industries,  including  agriculture,  trade,  fisheries, 
manufacturing, distribution, tourism, construction and transport. The highest concentration of 
assets is in trade (75% of the total loan portfolio as of the end of June 2011) and agriculture 
(14%).6 KICB intends to shift its portfolio to focus less on trade and more on production and 
asset generation to enable SMEs to thrive and grow. The SME portfolio has surpassed the 2010 
level as a proportion of the retail segment, and is currently expected to have an average growth 
rate of about 20%–30% per annum for the next 3 years; the retail portfolio is expected to grow 
to about 50% of the loan portfolio by 2013–2014. 
 
C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
1.  Ownership 
7.  KICB is owned by three development financial institutions, each of which own 17% of the 
bank’s shareholding: Deutsche Investitions- und Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH, EBRD, and 
IFC. Additional shareholders include the Aga Khan Fund for Economic Development (AKFED) 
(21%), Habib Bank of Pakistan (18%), and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic (10%). 
AKFED is the private sector investment agency of the Aga Khan Development Network. AKFED 
also has a 51% ownership stake in Habib Bank, which is the largest bank in Pakistan. Hence, 
effectively  AKFED  owns  30%  of  KICB.  Given  the  development  mandates  of  the  major 
shareholders, it is expected that they will be long-term investors. 
 
2.  Management 
8.  KICB’s senior management team is comprised of experienced banking executives who 
previously worked at various banks throughout Asia; they are responsible for managing the 
bank in conformity with its stated goals. The key senior positions are: (i) chief executive officer 
(CEO), (ii) chief banking officer, (iii) chief operating officer, (iv) chief corporate officer, (v) chief 
retail officer, and (vi) chief financial officer. The CEO (Kwan Young Choi) has 36 years of 
banking experience, including 15 in Central Asia, and 11 with KICB.7 
 
3.  Governance Structure 
9.  KICB is managed through various levels of corporate governance. KICB is overseen by 
a board of directors, which approves the bank's strategy, business plan, and corporate plan, 
reviews all of the bank's general policies and principles, and is involved with other matters 
relating to overall bank functioning as appropriate. There are three management committees—

committees report directly to the board. These committees facilitate management of KICB's 
operations, and the internal and external audit function. The board of directors comprises five 
nominee directors representing each shareholder with the exception of IFC.  
  
10.  The board of directors has overall responsibility for oversight of the risk management 
framework,  ensuring  that  management  of  key  risks  and  risk  management  policies  and 
procedures are implemented and followed. The head of the risk department is responsible for 
risk management and ensuring that implementation of controls and procedures are in place and 
adhered to. A monthly risk position report is provided to the board of directors and management 
on (i) the current position, and (ii) proposed recommendations to ensure that KICB is within the 
internal and central bank parameters.8 
 
11.  Credit is managed though a system of credit committees, and liquidity and market risks 
through the asset and liability committee. The asset and liability management committee (which 
is chaired by the CEO) approves risk limits, based on recommendations by the risk department. 
EBRD has provided TA for cash flow, credit, and SME business plan analysis. An experienced 
international risk management consultant is working closely and proactively with KICB, and the 
bank is adding internal staff to this function.9 
 
D.  Financial Performance 
1.  Current Performance 
12.  One of KICB’s primary strategic objectives is capital recovery through profit generation 
and retention by creating a strong market presence across all sectors of the business and 
general community. KICB increased its asset base considerably in 2011 as a result of the 
improvement in the investment climate. Total gross loans as of the end of August 2011 were 
$90 million. Total assets were $144.7 million as of 30 June 2011, an increase of 22% from the 
end of 2010. As of 30 June 2011, total loans were $70.9 million (up from $68.1 million at the end 
of 2010); deposits were $84.4 million (up from $71.9 million at the end of 2010). Demand for 
SME loans has increased considerably. From June 2010 to June 2011, KICB’s SME loan 
portfolio grew by 58% in dollar terms and by 23% in volume (from 1,953 to 2,420 loans). Total 
equity is $26.3 million. Table 1 provides an overview of KICB‘s financial performance through 
mid-2011.10

a.  Capitalization and Capital Adequacy 
13.  KICB has a strong capital adequacy ratio of 35.8% as of the end of June 2011, which is 
well above the 12% regulatory limit and the bank’s 15% internal limit. KICB’s tier 1 capital is 
29.1%. KICB’s level of capitalization has remained strong as a result of continued profitability 
and the recent $7.5 million equity injection from shareholders. Dividends were distributed for the 
first time in April 2011, amounting to $300,000. 
 
b.  Earnings 
14.  KICB’s financial performance from 2005 through 2009 was sound, as exhibited by a 
compounded annual growth rate for net income of 26%. Net income for the year ending 31 
December 2010 was $1.8 million, which represented a decrease of 42% from 2009 due to the 
political events in the Kyrgyz Republic, which resulted in KICB not being fully operational for a 
period  of  5  months.  However,  reporting  as  of  the  end  of  June  2011  shows  considerable 
improvement, with net income at $2.4 million, a 33% increase over the full year’s performance in 
2010. Operating income for 2010 was $10.4 million and $6.1 million for the 6 months ending 
June 30, 2011. The cost-to-income ratio decreased slightly to 59% in the first half of 2011 from 
60% as of the end of 2010. Costs reflect the increase in staffing as a result of the growing loan 
portfolio, opening of branches, and purchase of new software. Return on equity increased 1.6% 
from the 2010 level, reaching 9.5% for the first 6 months of 2011; return on assets increased 
0.2%  to  1.8%.  With  political  stability  and  an  improving  economic  environment,  growth  is 
expected to continue over the near term. 
 
c.  Funding and Liquidity 
15.  KICB has a strong funding and liquidity profile through customer deposits and external 
borrowings. The main funding source for KICB is deposits and international financial institution 
(IFI) loans. Deposits accounted for 60% of funding in 2010, and 58% for the first 6 months of 
2011. Approximately 73% of these deposits are demand deposits and 27% are time deposits.

5
KICB is targeting at least 30% deposit growth by 2012. Deposits had already grown by 22% as 
of the end of August 2011 (to $84.4 million). In addition to deposits, the other major source of 
funding is external borrowings (19.9%) and equity (18%). KICB has a minimum liquid assets-to-
short-term liabilities ratio of 30% (up to 30 days). As of the end of the second quarter of 2011, 
the liquidity ratio was 91% and the aggregate open currency position was 0.53%. As treasury 
bills command high interest rates (22% in June 2011) and are liquid, management plans to 
maintain government securities at about 7% of total assets over the next 3 years. 
 
16.  KICB has limited maturity mismatches (all buckets less than 100% of equity) as it has 
had access to mostly short-term funding and has, therefore, restricted its lending to relatively 
short-term  tenors.  KICB  has  insignificant  foreign  exchange  mismatches.  Given  that  the 
economy is largely dollar denominated, KICB’s portfolio comprises 88% US dollar loans; the 
income of these borrowers is generated primarily in US dollars.11 The maximum open foreign 
currency position a bank can hold per currency (other than US dollars) is 15% of capital; the 
aggregate open foreign currency position cannot exceed 20% of capital. 
 
d.  Asset Quality 
17.  KICB has a diversified loan portfolio across 17 sectors. It has a concentration limit of 
30%  per  sector  with  the  largest  single  exposure  in  trade  (27.5%);  other  sectors  include 
manufacturing (19.2%), tourism (6.3%), private households (24.9%), and agriculture (5.0%). 
The  majority  of  KICB’s  borrowers  are  based  in  the  outskirts  of  Bishkek.  The  20  largest 
borrowers account for 34.5% of KICB’s total portfolio. Related party exposure is minimal at 0.4% 
as of the end of June 2011.12 KICB has no outstanding loans to state-owned enterprises. 
 
18.  Most sectors of the economy were affected by the crisis. KICB’s nonperforming loans 
(NPLs)  increased  from  3.2%  in  2009  to  8.7%  in  2010,  which  was  lower  than  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic banking industry average of 15.8%.13 KICB’s segment with the largest proportion of 
NPLs  was  tourism  (7.7%).  The  tourism  sector  has  subsequently  rebounded  in  2011  as 
confidence continues to increase. As of the end of June 2011, KICB’s NPL ratio had further 
declined to 8.1%. KICB expects that NPLs will decrease to 5.6% in 2011 and to 4.6% in 2012 as 
a result of its ongoing efforts to strengthen its credit risk functions. All of KICB’s loans are 
backed by collateral with a loan-to-value ratio of 70% of the liquidation value and a loan-to-
income ratio of 70%. Provisioning increased significantly in 2010 to $2.08 million as a result of 
weakening asset quality.14 However, loan loss reserves amounted to only 63% of NPL’s in 
2010, compared with 95% in 2009. Provisioning as of the first 6 months of 2011 was already 
95%. As a precautionary measure, KICB allocated an additional amount of $2.3 million to a 
reserve  for  general  banking  risks,  increasing  their  provisions  to  105%  as  of  the  end  of 
December 2010.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
19.  ADB proposes extending a $10 million senior unsecured loan in two tranches to KICB 
with an overall tenor of 8 years.15 As noted, KICB will use ADB’s funds exclusively for onlending 
to SMEs. KICB’s needs for funding growth in its SME portfolio were carefully assessed, and 
compared with recently signed and anticipated facilities from other IFIs to estimate the funding 
gap.  
 
20.  Loan parameters. Eligible SMEs under the program are defined as small or medium-
sized enterprises that employ fewer than 200 employees and meet at least one of the following 
two criteria: (i) has annual revenues or sales up to a maximum of Som450,000,000 (about $10 
million); or (ii) has assets, the combined value of which do not exceed Som450, 000,000 (about 
$10 million). The definition is suitable for the market and conforms to the government’s SME 
definition. 
 
21.  Technical  assistance.  Capacity  development  TA  is  being  provided  under  ADB’s 
Capacity  Building  for  Financial  Institutions,  Phase  2,  approved  in  December  2010. 16  
Specifically, ADB will help strengthen KICB’s SME lending practices, which will complement 
ongoing TA from its strategic international shareholders and will be tailored to KICB’s needs in 
this area. The capacity development TA is expected to focus on improving credit assessment 
techniques  (e.g.,  assisting  KICB  develop  a  scorecard  for  SME  evaluation  and  portfolio 
management). Once KICB’s capacity building needs for its SME business are met, funds from 
the capacity development TA may also be used to help the bank build its mobile banking 
platform. In many developing countries, mobile banking is often the primary way in which SMEs 
conduct banking. 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  KICB  will  be  required  to  provide  the  following  information:  (i)  unaudited  financial 
statements  on  a  quarterly  basis,  (ii)  audited  financial  statements  on  an  annual  basis,  (iii) 
compliance certificates for agreed-upon financial covenants on a quarterly basis, (iv) reports on 
the  subborrowers  on  a  semiannual  basis,  and  (v)  an  annual  environmental  and  social 
performance report (including a report on onlending to SMEs owned or managed by women). 
Pursuant to the ADB Operations Manual, monitoring reports will be prepared and submitted to 
ADB on a regular basis, but at least annually.17 The first monitoring report will be submitted no 
later than 12 months after ADB Board of Directors approval. 
   
C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
23.  The loan will provide critically needed long-term funding to SMEs in the Kyrgyz Republic 
whose ability to access funds has been constrained by the country’s low level of financial sector 
development (FSD)—including the absence of a well-developed capital market—which limits 
availability of such funding. Moreover, SMEs were particularly impacted by the 2010 political 
crisis;  although  recovering,  they  need  funding  to  support  future  growth.  The  capacity 
development TA will provide KICB with support to prudently expand and increase the efficiency 
and sustainability of services to SMEs, thereby supporting the SME sector’s contribution to 
overall economic growth and employment generation in the Kyrgyz Republic.

D.  Risks 
24.  Aggressive  Business  Strategy  in  SME  Lending  and  Asset  Quality  Risks. 
Previously, KICB has catered to corporate customers and is now shifting its focus towards 
SMEs. Currently, NPLs have declined to 7.8% as of the end of June 2011 (from 11.9% as of the 
end  of  2010)  and  KICB  expects  that  NPLs  will  continue  to  decline18.    ADB  will  evaluate 
implementation of KICB’s business plan as well as the performance of the SME business prior 
to the disbursement of the second tranche.19  
 
25.  Evolving  Risk  Management.  KICB  is  taking  further  steps  to  further  strengthen  its 
underwriting and SME capacity to adapt to the shift in focus toward SME lending. ADB’s 
capacity development TA will be critical to help strengthen KICB’s SME lending practices and 
safeguard asset quality as the bank’s business in this segment expands.  
 
26.  Political Risk. The Kyrgyz Republic continues to recover from the political crisis in 2010. 
The shift to a parliamentary democracy has provided a unique opportunity to break with the past 
and strengthen governance and reform the economy. The political situation is improving and the 
elections were carried out peacefully.20GDP is projected to expand by 6% on average through 
2013 and the country’s overall outlook is positive, assuming continued political stability.   
 
27.  Sustainability  of  funding  for  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  lending.  The 
Kyrgyz Republic’s banking system is small by international standards and the local capital 
markets  are  undeveloped.  This  limits  funding  sources  for  banks,  which  must  depend  on 
deposits and financial support from IFIs such as ADB. When ADB’s loan expires, KICB may 
need to seek additional funding from external sources. KICB is increasing its deposit base and 
enjoys support from strong shareholders and other IFIs. The lasting impact of this loan, in 
addition to the funding enabling KICB to provide access to longer-term funding for the country’s 
SMEs, will be sustainable development of KICB's SME-lending activities in the future through 
ADB’s capacity development TA.  
 
28.  Foreign Currency Risk. ADB’s investment will be denominated in US dollars and, as 
such, there will be an element of foreign exchange risk. The primary mitigation for this risk is 
that KICB’s functional currency is the US dollar, and the majority of its financial assets and 
liabilities are denominated in dollars (e.g. 75% of KICB deposits are in US dollars). KICB 
mitigates  this  risk  through  its  credit  assessment  process,  where  US  dollar  borrowers  are 
required to have at least 50% of their planned income in US dollars. 
IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
29.  Impact. Increasing the SME sector’s share in the economy will help contribute to broad-
based GDP growth. Supporting SME development by increasing access to finance as a result of 
the positive demonstration effect from ADB’s loan can help raise total employment, and lead to 
inclusive economic growth. 
 
30.  Outcome. ADB’s loan and capacity development TA is expected to help KICB establish 
a  profitable  and  sustainable  SME  program  and  broaden  access  to  finance  for  previously 
unbanked SMEs.  
 
                                                 
18 NPL’s as calculated by ADB. 
19 The second tranche is up to $5m. 
20 Presidential elections in the Kyrgyz Republic were held on 30 October 2011.

8  
31.  Outputs.  This loan will provide KICB with additional funds for onlending to SMEs. 
Outputs  include  KICB  having  access  to  longer-term  funds  for  SME  onlending,  which  will 
increase its lending activities to this sector. Additional output of this project will be product 
development in KICB, supported by TA from ADB. Reporting of sex-disaggregated data will be 
undertaken as appropriate. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 
32.  Strategy 2020 identifies private sector development and private sector operations as one 
of the five drivers of change to mobilize resources to help alleviate poverty in the region, and  
FSD is noted as one of the five operating areas that will be undertaken in support of this 
agenda.21  The proposed investment is consistent with the government’s priorities and desires 
to  encourage  economic  growth,  broaden  access  to  finance,  address  low  private  sector 
investment, and reduce unemployment.22 Expanding access to finance via banks and increasing 
private sector investments with development impact potential is one of the objectives set forth in 
the country operation business plan, 2011–2012.23 The project is consistent with Strategy 2020 
and the country operations business plan as it will support private sector development through 
FSD by increasing the capacity and ability of KICB to expand its lending activities to SMEs, 
which comprise an important and underserved portion of the Kyrgyz Republic’s economy. The 
new 3-year country partnership strategy is currently being drafted and will be completed in 
2012. Broadening access to finance through private sector interventions in the banking sector is 
expected to continue to be an ongoing priority for the country. ADB’s Investment Climate 
Improvement Program, subprogram 2, will include a component aimed at improving access to 
finance.24  The policy reforms to be implemented under this loan are expected to complement 
this project by increasing the capacity of financial institutions to provide finance to Kyrgyz firms. 
 
2.  Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations 
33.  The Kyrgyz Republic is at a “nascent” stage of FSD. Under the PSCM Business Plan 
and Priorities, 2010–2012,25 ADB’s response is to assist stronger private banks with loans, 
equity, and TA to support early movers. ADB intervention in such situations will likely involve a 
long process, with repeat and follow-on loans from ADB or other IFI programs. The Financial 
Sector Operational Plan26 calls for enhanced financial inclusion of the traditionally underserved, 
including SMEs, which will lead to inclusive growth, one of the three strategic agendas of 
Strategy 2020. It recognizes that the region’s “base of the pyramid”27 and SMEs have yet to gain 
adequate access to financial services. The plan notes that capacity building for participating 
intermediaries and end-borrowers in credit assessment should be supported. This project will 
thus support FSD through expansion of access to finance for SMEs.

Manila. 
22 ADB. 2009. The Kyrgyz Republic Country Development Strategy for 2009–2011. Kyrgyz Republic. 
23 ADB. 2011. The Kyrgyz Republic: Country Operations Business Plan, 2011–2012. Manila (IN.125-11, 13 July). 
This covers only a 2-year period because a new country partnership strategy will be prepared in 2012. 
24 Investment Climate Improvement Program, Subprogram 2 System Support Project–Consultation and Review

9
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Environment and Social Safeguards 
34.  The investment is classified as category FI (treated as C) for environment, involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous peoples under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). KICB’s 
existing environmental and social management systems (ESMS) or equivalent systems have 
been reviewed, areas requiring improvements have been identified and effective measures to 
address them are laid out in the ESMS arrangement.28 KICB will (i) apply ADB’s prohibited 
investment activities list, (ii) screen and exclude all projects that will have adverse environment 
and  social  safeguards  impacts,  (iii)  ensure  that  investments  using  ADB  funds  abide  by 
applicable  national  laws  and  regulations,  and  (iv)  comply  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009). KICB will be assisted by ADB to enhance their ESMS, which is integrated in 
their Credit Department Operations Manual and (i) incorporates ADB’s prohibited investment 
activities  list  and  the  screening  and  reporting  procedures,  and  (ii)  complies  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). A revised operations manual will be submitted to ADB prior 
to the first disbursement. The ESMS will include arrangements to comply with national labor 
laws and ADB Social Protection Strategy (2001) to ensure adherence with core labor standards. 
 
35.  SMEs owned or managed by women constitute more than 40% of the loan applications 
processed and approved by KICB from 2007 to 2010. KICB will continue to track and target 
maintenance of this level of onlending to SMEs owned or managed by women until 2016. The 
Kyrgyz Republic has ratified all conventions related to core labor standards, and KICB’s annual 
reports  will  include  a  report  on  compliance  with  core  labor  standards  by  KICB  and  their 
customers that use ADB funds. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
36.  KICB has been advised of ADB’s anticorruption policy and its policy of implementing 
best international practice relating to the combating of money laundering and the financing of 
terrorism. ADB will ensure that the investment documentation between ADB and KICB includes 
appropriate anticorruption provisions and remedies for ADB in the event of non-compliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations  
37.  The proposed transaction, once approved and signed, will increase ADB's projected 
nonsovereign exposure by June 2012 to $7.52 billion. It will increase nonsovereign exposure to 
the Kyrgyz Republic to $10 million or 0.13% of total nonsovereign exposure, increase exposure 
in the finance sector to $3.13 billion or 42% of total nonsovereign exposure, and the domestic 
commercial bank subsector to $536.3 million or 7.1% of total nonsovereign exposure. The 
projected weighted average risk rating of the portfolio (as of 30 June 2012) will remain at 6.5 
after inclusion of the $10 million loan to KICB. The proposed financing is within ADB’s approved 
medium-term,  country,  industry  single  obligor,  and  group  exposure  limits  for  nonsovereign 
investment. 
 
38.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank, 29  the 
Government of the Kyrgyz Republic will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the 
proposed assistance to KICB. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and 
substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by its Board of 
Directors. 
 
                                                 
28 Financial Intermediary: Environmental and Social Management System Arrangement (accessible from the linked 
documents in Appendix 2). 
29 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

10  
VI.  RECOMMENDATIONS 
39.  I am satisfied that the proposed senior unsecured loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the 
Board approve the loan of up to $10,000,000 to the Kyrgyz Investment and Credit Bank for 
small and medium-sized enterprise finance in the Kyrgyz Republic from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
40.  I also recommend that the Board approve the proposal set out in para. 24 of this report 
to permit the proceeds of this loan to be used for procurement in non-member countries and for 
procurement  of  goods  and  services  produced  in  non-member  countries.  If  the  requisite 
affirmative vote of directors representing not less than two-thirds of the total voting power of 
ADB's  members,  pursuant  to  Article  14(ix)  of  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian 
Development Bank, is not obtained for this recommendation and the Board only approves the 
recommendation in para 42, then the proceeds of this loan shall be used only for procurement in 
member countries of goods and services produced in member countries. 
 
 
Bindu N. Lohani 
Vice President 
23 November 2011
